Two-stage designs

Source: R/TwoStageDesign.R
TwoStageDesign-class.Rd

TwoStageDesign is the fundamental design class of this package. It consits of three first-stage parameters, two-stage two vectors and additional parameters for implementation.

This function allows to plot the stage-two sample size and decision boundary functions of a TwoStageDesign and user-defined elements of the class ConditionalScore.

TwoStageDesign(...)

# S4 method for numeric
TwoStageDesign(n1, c1f, c1e, n2_pivots, c2_pivots,
  x1_norm_pivots, weights)

Arguments

...

optional arguments depending on implementation
n1

cf. slot
c1f

cf. slot
c1e

cf. slot
n2_pivots

cf. slot
c2_pivots

cf. slot
x1_norm_pivots

cf. slot
weights

cf. slot
x

design
object

object to update
params

vector of design parameters (must be in same order as returned by as.numeric(design))
d

design object
x1

stage-one outcome
y

not used
rounded

should n-values be rounded?
k

number of points to use for plotting
nsim

number of simulation runs
dist

data distribution
theta

location parameter of the data distribution
seed

random seed

Details

n1 denotes the sample size of the first stage. c1f and c1e define decision boundary. If the first-stage test statistic Z_1 is larger than c1e, than the trial is stopped early for efficacy and the null hypothesis is rejected. If Z_1 is smaller than c1f, than the null hypothesis is accpected and the trial is stopped early for futility. Otherwise, the trial enters in the second stage. In this case, the stage-two sample size function n2(Z_1) and the stage-two rejection boundary c2(Z_1) are computed. As these are functions, they are approximated by a vector of pivots denoted by n2_pivots and c2_pivots, respectively. The slots x1_norm_pivots and weights are defined for numerical implementation rules. The generic implementation of this package is a Gaussian quadrature and a corresponding design can be built by means of gq_design. The user is free to implement own integration rules. He has to be aware that all elements of x1_norm_pivots have to be inside the interval [-1, 1] and have to be scaled by the applied integration rule. The parameter tunable is a logical one and indicates which design parameters should be tunable for use in optimization. Rounded sample size values can be applied by the logical parameter rounded.

Methods (by generic)

  • n: overall sample size given stage-one outcome

  • scaled_integration_pivots: get the actual pivots points (knots) of the numerical integration routine rule.

  • simulate: simulate from the given design under parameter theta.

Slots

n1

stage-one sample size

c1f

early stopping for futility boundary

c1e

early stopping for efficacy boundary

n2_pivots

vector of length order giving the values of n2 at the pivot points of the numeric integration rule [TODO: these are not available during construction]

c2_pivots

vector of length order giving the values of c2 at the pivot points of the numeric integration rule [TODO: these are not available during construction]

x1_norm_pivots

normalized pivots for integration rule (in [-1, 1])

weights

weights of conditional score values at x1_norm_pivots for approximating the integral over x1.

tunable

named logical vector indicating whether corresponding slot is considered a tunable parameter

rounded

logical that indicates whether rounded n-values should be used

Examples

order  <- 5L
design <- gq_design(50, 0, 2, rep(50.0, order), rep(2.0, order), order)
cp     <- ConditionalPower(dist = Normal(), prior = PointMassPrior(.4, 1))
plot(design, "Conditional Power" = cp)
